item.title: Salah Abdeslam, Suspect in Paris Attacks, Is Captured in Brussels
item.description: Mr. Abdeslam had evaded the authorities for four months; his fingerprint was found in a residence raided by the police this week.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:credit: Belgian Federal Police, via Associated Press

item.title: How We Got to a Colombian Guerrilla Camp
item.description: The reporter Nicholas Casey describes the path he took to meet the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY
item.media:credit: Nicholas Casey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicholas Casey, on a motorcycle, heading to a Latin American guerrilla camp.

item.title: Morocco Orders U.N. to Cut Staff in Disputed Western Sahara Territory
item.description: Reacting to comments from the U.N. leader, Morocco demanded the evacuation of 84 members of the organization’s mission in Western Sahara, where it has played a peacemaking role for 25 years.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: A protest in Rabat, Morocco, this week against statements made by the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, about Western Sahara.

item.title: In a Rebel Camp in Colombia, Marx and Free Love Reign
item.description: For the guerrillas of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, many of whom have never set foot in their country’s cities, the prospect of peace after 50 years means an uncertain future.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY
item.media:credit: Federico Rios Escobar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rebel named Andrea drew on Michael’s shoulder in one of the FARC’s jungle camps. While the guerrillas reject marriage, relationships among them are common.

item.title: European Union Reaches Deal With Turkey to Return New Asylum Seekers
item.description: The move to send migrants who arrive in Greece back to Turkey was a significant step amid a crisis that has left tens of thousands of people in squalid conditions.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: A migrant child sat by a fire at a camp in Idomeni, Greece, near the country’s northern border with Macedonia, on Friday.

item.title: Guido Westerwelle Dies at 54; German Foreign Minister Opposed Libya Incursion
item.description: A former leader of the Free Democratic Party, Mr. Westerwelle became the highest-ranking openly gay person in the German government.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Guido Westerwelle, then the German foreign minister, and Chancellor Angela Merkel at a session of the Bundestag in Berlin in 2011.

item.title: Obama to Unseal Files on Argentina’s ‘Dirty War’
item.description: President Obama is moving to declassify records that could show what the United States knew about Argentina’s brutal crackdowns of the 1970s and ’80s.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Wave of Indigenous Suicides Leaves Canadian Town Appealing for Help
item.description: Six people have killed themselves and over 140 have attempted suicide or expressed a desire to do it in the Cree Indian community of Cross Lake, setting off a public health crisis.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.media:description: Cross Lake, Manitoba, which includes about 6,000 people, has confronted a suicide crisis in recent months.

item.title: U.N. Condemns Airstrikes That Killed 106 in Yemen
item.description: A Saudi-led coalition carried out the attacks, which appear to be the deadliest yet in its yearlong intervention in the civil war.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Ex-Professor Upsets Ukraine Politics, and Russia Peace Accord
item.description: Oksana I. Syroyid has shot to the top of politics in Ukraine by trying to derail a peace accord with Russia.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oksana I. Syroyid, the deputy speaker of Ukraine’s Parliament, has blocked passage of a constitutional amendment seen as central to the Minsk II peace accord with Russia.

item.title: Gas Facility in Algeria Is Attacked With Rockets
item.description: The identities of the attackers, who struck the site that is jointly operated by Statoil and BP, were not known, and there were no immediate reports of injuries.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: What’s in the E.U. Deal With Turkey? Controls, Concessions and Swaps
item.description: Leaders of the European Union and Turkey reached an agreement to help resolve the migrant crisis. Here’s what it means for migrants and Turkey.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Syrian migrants at the Greek military-run Mazaraki camp near the village of Cherso, Greece, last week.

item.title: A Lion Escapes a Kenyan National Park Again, Injuring a Man
item.description: It was the fourth time in less than a month that one of the animals at a Nairobi reserve escaped and headed into the capital.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: China Is Said to Be Holding Jia Jia, a Journalist, Over Xi Jinping Letter
item.description: The letter, which Mr. Jia’s friends said he denied writing, was an incendiary denunciation of the Chinese president that implied threats to his safety.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.media:description: Under President Xi Jinping, the Chinese government has taken an increasingly hard line toward dissent, imprisoning dozens of activists, lawyers and journalists.

item.title: Opinion: I Love the U.N., but It Is Failing
item.description: I joined to protect the helpless from rape and murder. I never dreamed our own forces would be the rapists and murderers.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: ANTHONY BANBURY

item.title: Sinosphere: On Social Media in China, Size 0 Doesn’t Make the Cut
item.description: Women and a few men in China are boasting about their thinness by posting photographs of their waists hidden behind a piece of A4 paper.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A 24-year-old Chinese student who did not want her full name to be used holding up a piece of paper to show the slimness of her waist.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Obama's Flawed Realism
item.description: The president has sold American power short. Trump's American irredentism feeds off this.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Chinese Tycoon Criticizes Leader, and Wins Surprising Support
item.description: The unexpected defense of an outspoken real estate tycoon has exposed uneasiness about President Xi Jinping’s calls for unquestioning public obedience.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Ren Zhiqiang, an outspoken property developer, at a book club in Wuhan, China, in September. Mr. Ren’s social media accounts, which had tens of millions of followers, were erased after he posted remarks critical of President Xi Jinping.

item.title: Sinosphere: With ‘Smog Jog’ Through Beijing, Zuckerberg Stirs Debate on Air Pollution
item.description: When Mark Zuckerberg, of Facebook, posted a photo of his run Friday, he set off reactions that ranged from mocking to genuine concern about his health.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR

item.title: Sinosphere: China Resumes Diplomatic Relations With Gambia, Shutting Out Taiwan
item.description: The move raised the prospect of a renewed contest between China and Taiwan over allies, as Gambia had maintained ties to Taiwan for nearly 20 years.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The foreign minister of Gambia, Neneh MacDouall Gaye, with the vice president of China, Li Yuanchao, in Beijing this week.
